title: Avoid Intel Says Advisors Capital’s Feeney
description: Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan is set to meet with President Donald Trump after the US leader called for his resignation. Advisors Capital Management’s JoAnne Feeney addresses the position Intel finds itself in and why she thinks investors should avoid the stock right now. She speaks with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Tech.”  (Source: Bloomberg)

Is it better that he promises more investment into the US, more manufacturing and that he has extricated himself from China? Or ultimately, does he even need to stand down in some way as CEO? Yeah, it's really I think it's really unclear, Caroline. Obviously, I think he can defend himself from the concerns that that he's conflicted, and that's his main mission today. I don't know if that means he needs to do more to separate from his prior work and investments. I don't know how much capacity he has to do that. I think Ian is right that the administration wants to be able to continue to push the narrative that they are doing something to bring more chip manufacturing back to the U.S. And so his announcements of less investment or delayed investment is a concern to the administration, but they don't have the customers yet. Maybe he can say, hey, we've got these guys on the line, we're reeling them in. Maybe that would be reassuring. But ultimately, Intel needs to keep those subsidies, but not at the cost of having to spend so much CapEx in the near term when they don't have customers. So a very fine line for more of a CEO to walk here. The stock's up 6%. So the market like something about the idea that Bhutan's going to go to D.C. and meet with the president. And so he seems like he's a very good person to run Intel at this point. So, you know, it's definitely going to be a hit to margins on a what is a, you know, my minority part of their businesses. Right. It's unconstitutional to impose an export tax like this. But it's not clear who would have the legal standing to object to the tax. And clearly, NVIDIA and AMD aren't going to because they don't want to unbalance the applecart here and risk those export export licenses. But perhaps, you know, one of the business associations does it's unclear or whether this shouldn't stand. But, you know, we're seeing more and more of these kinds of pay to play arrangements by the U.S. government that could increasingly put a tax on businesses and should be known. This is an ex post tax break. This has happened after the fact of the companies having designed these chips and begun to sell them and they want to sell more. What we're worried about is that now companies are going to take this potentially into account. You know, do I want to develop the next chip or do I want to develop the next, you know, whatever medical device, if I'm going to be subject to a 15% revenue tax.
summary: Investors Capital's Joanne Feeney and Joanne Lefeny have highlighted the uncertainty surrounding Intel's CEO, CEO Lipton, regarding promises of increased investment into the US, more manufacturing, and removing himself from China. They suggest that Lipton may need to separate himself from his prior work and investments, but ultimately Intel needs to keep subsidies, but not at the cost of having to spend so much CapEx when they don't have customers. They also express concern about the potential for Intel to make a comeback, while uncertainties loom large about access to China and the cost-effectiveness of AMD and NVIDIA deals. They argue that the companies are better off with access to the country than without a 15% export tax, which could significantly impact their margins. However, they also warn that the potential revenue at risk of $38 billion for Intel and AMD could potentially grow over time, potentially cutting margins.
shortSummary: Joanne Feeney questions CEO Lipton's future role amid uncertainties over Intel's investment, manufacturing, and access to China, impacting investor confidence.
argos_summary: The discussion revolves around Intel's CEO navigating challenges related to U.S. manufacturing and investments, particularly in light of concerns about his connections to China. There are uncertainties regarding Intel's ability to recover market share from competitors like AMD and NVIDIA, especially with new export taxes affecting revenue. Despite these challenges, there is cautious optimism about potential revenue from China for AMD and NVIDIA, as they secure export licenses, although the impact of the 15% tax on margins remains a concern.
